page.title: 05Experimental Horticulture
page.content: Stockbridge House Experimental Horticultural Station is a government funded experimental farm carrying out basic research into crops for commercial development. It covers 150 acres of fine light sandy soil and employs 40 people.It is situated on flat open land but an important feature of the site is a shelter belt, planted by, a former director, consisting of Leylandii, deciduous trees, and a beech hedge. Crops are grown under glass and polythene as well as outdoors. Glasshouse crops include tomatoes, cucumber and lettuce. Other crops are soft fruits, rhubarb,cabbage,corn,calabrese,rape, potatoes, and red beet. Crops are generally marketed on the open market. Development has remained static of late and the future depends on the availabilty of government funding.
